<h2><a id="user-content-ascii" class="anchor" href="#ascii" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>ASCII</h2>

<ul>
<li>short for American  Standard  Code for  Information  Interchange (1960, Bell Data)</li>
<li>developed from telegraph code (such as Morse code)</li>
<li>enables text representation on computers, screens and  communication devices</li>
<li>uses 7-bit binary integers</li>
<li>encodes 128 specified characters, numbers 0-9, letters a-z, A-Z, some basic punctuation, and (some now obsolete) control codes</li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="user-content-ascii-reference-card" class="anchor" href="#ascii-reference-card" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>ASCII reference card</h2>

<p><a href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/d30c11ee876572361cc856d49b5db2a204ec5c2b/68747470733a2f2f75706c6f61642e77696b696d656469612e6f72672f77696b6970656469612f636f6d6d6f6e732f382f38322f55532d41534349495f636f64655f63686172742e706e67" target="_blank"><img src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/d30c11ee876572361cc856d49b5db2a204ec5c2b/68747470733a2f2f75706c6f61642e77696b696d656469612e6f72672f77696b6970656469612f636f6d6d6f6e732f382f38322f55532d41534349495f636f64655f63686172742e706e67" alt="ASCII image" width="650" data-canonical-src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/US-ASCII_code_chart.png" style="max-width:100%;"></a></p>

<h2><a id="user-content-ascii-1" class="anchor" href="#ascii-1" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>ASCII</h2>

<ul>
<li>printable characters: 100 0001=A, 100 0010=B, 110 0001=a, 110 0010=b, ...</li>
<li>first 32 chars are for control, e.g. 000 1000=BS=backspace, 111 1111=DEL=delete, </li>
<li>horizontal tab (000 1001=HT \t), line feed (000 1010=LF \n) and carriage return (000 1101=CR \r) are also control codes</li>
<li>Advantage of ASCII: human readable, less prone to error/can be humanly checked</li>
</ul>

<p>[<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ascii">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ascii</a>]</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-ascii-and-r" class="anchor" href="#ascii-and-r" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>ASCII and R</h2>

<ul>
<li>base R supports reading ASCII files, e.g. <code>read.table(), read.csv(), read.delim()</code> reads data from ASCII files with specified delimiters </li>
<li><code>write.table()</code> writes ASCII files</li>
<li>the <code>readr</code> package provides similar functionality: <code>read_csv, read_tsv, read_delim</code></li>
<li><code>readr</code> functions are faster than base R functions, if the whole file is being read at once</li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="user-content-binary-file-formats" class="anchor" href="#binary-file-formats" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Binary file formats</h2>

<ul>
<li>No restriction in terms on content, streams of bytes</li>
<li>Advantage: Generally much smaller files, and with compression even smaller, e.g. <code>nasadata.csv</code> is 3.7Mb, <code>nasadata.rds</code> is 288kb</li>
<li>Disadvantage: Can be machine-dependent</li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="user-content-binary-files-and-r" class="anchor" href="#binary-files-and-r" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Binary files and R</h2>

<ul>
<li><code>saveRDS()</code> saves a single R object in binary format, use extension <code>.rds</code></li>
<li><code>readRDS()</code> reads R binary file</li>
<li><code>save()</code> saves all objects in a binary file (and keeps their names), use extension <code>.rda</code> </li>
<li><code>load()</code> retrieves these objects (using the same names)</li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="user-content-example" class="anchor" href="#example" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Example</h2>

<h2><a id="user-content-awkward-text-formats-and-r" class="anchor" href="#awkward-text-formats-and-r" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Awkward text formats and R</h2>

<p>The National Climate Data Center at NOAA publishes information on temperature and precipation across a network of stations in the US.</p>

<p>The Data can be accessed through ftp at <a href="ftp://ftp.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/ushcn/v2.5">ftp://ftp.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/ushcn/v2.5</a>, a code book with a description of the data structure is available at
<a href="ftp://ftp.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/ushcn/v2.5/readme.txt">ftp://ftp.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/ushcn/v2.5/readme.txt</a></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">temp.all</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span>readLines(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>../data/USH00132999.raw.tmax<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">n</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">5</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">temp.all</span></pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-from-the-code-book" class="anchor" href="#from-the-code-book" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>From the code book</h2>

</code></pre>

<h2><a id="user-content-fixed-width-format" class="anchor" href="#fixed-width-format" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Fixed width format</h2>

<ul>
<li>Fixed formats can be read with <code>read.fwf()</code> or <code>readr::read_fwf()</code></li>
<li>Need to specify column positions: pretty painful to specify</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">tidyverse</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">temps</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read_fwf(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>../data/USH00132999.raw.tmax<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,
  <span class="pl-v">col_positions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> fwf_positions(
    <span class="pl-v">start</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>c( <span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">13</span>, rep(<span class="pl-c1">16</span><span class="pl-k">+</span><span class="pl-c1">9</span><span class="pl-k">*</span><span class="pl-c1">0</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-c1">11</span>, <span class="pl-v">each</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">7</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>,<span class="pl-c1">9</span>)), 
    <span class="pl-v">end</span>  <span class="pl-k">=</span>c(<span class="pl-c1">11</span>,<span class="pl-c1">16</span>, rep(<span class="pl-c1">16</span><span class="pl-k">+</span><span class="pl-c1">9</span><span class="pl-k">*</span><span class="pl-c1">0</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-c1">11</span>, <span class="pl-v">each</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">6</span>,<span class="pl-c1">7</span>,<span class="pl-c1">8</span>,<span class="pl-c1">9</span>))))
names(<span class="pl-smi">temps</span>) <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Station<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Year<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, 
  paste0(rep(c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Value<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>DMflag<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>QCflag<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>DSflag<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>), <span class="pl-c1">12</span>), 
         rep(<span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-c1">12</span>, <span class="pl-v">each</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">4</span>)))</pre></div>

<h2></h2>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">FortDodge</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">temps</span> %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>% 
  gather(<span class="pl-v">key</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Month<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">value</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Temp_Max<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, starts_with(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Value<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
<span class="pl-smi">FortDodge</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Month</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> as.numeric(gsub(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Value<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">FortDodge</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Month</span>))
<span class="pl-smi">FortDodge</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Temp_Max</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> replace(<span class="pl-smi">FortDodge</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Temp_Max</span>, 
                              <span class="pl-smi">FortDodge</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">Temp_Max</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">9999</span>, <span class="pl-c1">NA</span>)

<span class="pl-smi">FortDodge</span> %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>% ggplot(aes(<span class="pl-v">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">Year</span>, <span class="pl-smi">Temp_Max</span><span class="pl-k">/</span><span class="pl-c1">100</span>)) <span class="pl-k">+</span> 
  geom_point() <span class="pl-k">+</span> facet_wrap(<span class="pl-k">~</span><span class="pl-smi">Month</span>, <span class="pl-v">nrow</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>) </pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-your-turn-10-min" class="anchor" href="#your-turn-10-min" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Your turn (10 min)</h2>

<p>The file <code>ushcn-v2.5-stations.txt</code> contains information on all weather stations in the USHCN network. This file is also in fixed width format.
<strong>Read the file into R and plot latitude versus longitude.</strong></p>

<pre><code>    ----------------------------------------
    Variable             Columns    Type
    ----------------------------------------
    COUNTRY CODE             1-2    Character
    NETWORK CODE               3    Character
    ID PLACEHOLDERS ("00")   4-5    Character
    COOP ID                 6-11    Character
    LATITUDE               13-20    Real
    LONGITUDE              22-30    Real
    ELEVATION              33-37    Real
    STATE                  39-40    Character
    NAME                   42-71    Character
    COMPONENT 1 (COOP ID)  73-78    Character
    COMPONENT 2 (COOP ID)  80-85    Character
    COMPONENT 3 (COOP ID)  87-92    Character
    UTC OFFSET             94-95    Integer
    -----------------------------------------
</code></pre>

<h2><a id="user-content-html-files" class="anchor" href="#html-files" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>HTML FILES</h2>

<ul>
<li>A lot of data is available online in the form of html tables</li>
<li>Extracting the data requires recognizing the html table format, and stripping off the html</li>
<li>The package <code>xml</code> helps with this</li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="user-content-html-files-1" class="anchor" href="#html-files-1" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>HTML FILES</h2>

<p>Pulling election polls off the web...</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">rvest</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">url</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>http://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/iowa<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
<span class="pl-smi">doc</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read_html(<span class="pl-smi">url</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">tables</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> html_table(<span class="pl-smi">doc</span>, <span class="pl-v">fill</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>)
head(<span class="pl-smi">tables</span>[[<span class="pl-c1">2</span>]])</pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-other-binary-formats-and-r" class="anchor" href="#other-binary-formats-and-r" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Other binary formats and R</h2>

<ul>
<li>Packages <code>foreign</code> or <code>haven</code>: Data export/import for other (statistical) software: Stata, Epi, Octave, SPSS, Systat, SAS</li>
<li>Package <code>readxl</code> import/export with Excel spreadsheets
e.g. web index data at <a href="http://www.visualizing.org/datasets/web-index-2013">http://www.visualizing.org/datasets/web-index-2013</a></li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">foreign</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">knights</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.spss(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>../data/knightfoundation2008sotcdata.por<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
str(<span class="pl-smi">knights</span>)</pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-json" class="anchor" href="#json" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>JSON</h2>

<ul>
<li>JSON is short for JavaScript  Object Notation (<a href="http://json.org/">http://json.org/</a>) </li>
<li>it is a lightweight data interchange format, becoming popular</li>
<li>Human readable and writable</li>
<li>Utilized by many web APIs, e.g. tumblr, twitter, ... </li>
<li>... and also the Census Bureau!</li>
</ul>

<p>e.g. result from get query in JSON format:</p>

<pre><code>[["P0010001","NAME","state"],
 ["710231","Alaska","02"],
 ["4779736","Alabama","01"],
 ["2915918","Arkansas","05"],
 ["6392017","Arizona","04"],
 ["37253956","California","06"]]
</code></pre>

<p>i.e. vector of vector format - focus is on individual rows in a data set, whereas R puts emphasis on individual columns (data set is list of vectors).</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-example-census-bureau-api" class="anchor" href="#example-census-bureau-api" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Example: Census Bureau API</h2>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">devtools</span>)
<span class="pl-k">if</span> (<span class="pl-k">!</span>require(<span class="pl-smi">cbapi</span>)) {
  install_github(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>heike/cbapi<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>) <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> run this the first time </span>
  library(<span class="pl-smi">cbapi</span>)
}
setkey(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>7f784587c3918611ad6ca67188d9b269b3558dd4<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>) <span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> my key - if you want to use this, get your own :)</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> population based on 2010 Census:</span>
<span class="pl-smi">popstate</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.census(sprintf(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>http://api.census.gov/data/2010/sf1?key=%s&amp;get=P0010001,NAME&amp;for=state:*<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, getkey()))
head(<span class="pl-smi">popstate</span>)</pre></div>

<h2><a id="user-content-why-do-we-need-to-access-all-these-formats" class="anchor" href="#why-do-we-need-to-access-all-these-formats" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Why do we need to access all these formats?</h2>

<ul>
<li>To solve a problem, may need to collate data from multiple sources</li>
<li>Rearranging and merging data from different sources helps to pull together the data necessary to solve the problem</li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="user-content-reading-and-blog" class="anchor" href="#reading-and-blog" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Reading and blog</h2>

<p>Watch the talk Prof Donald Knuth gave at the useR!2016. Based on that, answer the following questions:</p>

<ul>
<li>What role does literate programming play in your life so far?</li>
<li>Where do you see potential in applying literate programming in your workflow?</li>
</ul>

<p>Make a blog entry by 10 pm Tuesday, Jan 24.</p>
